docs.lead_paragraph: The Black Ministers Council of New Jersey yesterday called for a 2 to 3 percent tax on health insurance premiums to reimburse New Jersey hospitals for providing charity care to uninsured people, mainly the working poor, The Associated Press reported. Last year, the state paid $400 million for hospital charity care, but so far this year the funds have not been renewed. JOE SHARKEY

headline.main: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Plan for Hospital Care

docs.lead_paragraph: A NEW study reports that medical care, adjusted for local costs of living, costs twice as much in some areas of the country as it does in others. And the use of specific medical treatments, like surgery for breast cancer or prostate cancer, varies strikingly, depending on where a patient lives. For instance, in some parts of the country radical mastectomies were performed 33 times as often as breast-saving lumpectomies for women with breast cancer.

headline.main: Sharp Regional Incongruity Found In Medical Costs and Treatments

docs.lead_paragraph: An unintended quirk in Federal law threatens to strip about 640 chronically ill New Yorkers of their private health insurance with Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield. Some advocates for the potential victims have fingered Empire as the villain. But Empire did not create the problem, nor can Empire solve it. About 60,000 New Yorkers buy individual policies (as opposed to group coverage) from Empire because no other insurer sells the unprofitable product. Empire loses about $75 million a year on these individuals. Some $2 million of the losses are accounted for by 640 disabled people who kept their Empire policies even after they qualified for Medicare because the Empire plan covers benefits, like drugs, that Medicare does not.

docs.lead_paragraph: The cost of employees' health care resumed its climb last year after a surprising dip in 1994. And the upward trend is apparently continuing in 1996, according to surveys of employers published yesterday by two big benefits consulting firms. The rise was almost entirely in the cost of traditional health insurance. Health care costs for participants in managed-care networks fell for the first time last year, down 3.8 percent from 1994. Such networks now cover 71 percent of all workers who have insurance provided by their employers, compared with 63 percent a year ago.

headline.main: Survey Finds Health Costs Rose in '95

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's budget message, as transcribed by The New York Times. To achieve our tax cuts and spending cuts, we've had to make tough choices from the moment we arrived in Trenton. We have gone after runaway spending items that were increasing well beyond the taxpayers' ability to pay. We have stopped overfunding the state pension and retiree benefits system. We have contained increases in state salaries and benefits while being fair to employees. We are bringing Medicaid costs under control. And we've worked with local governments and school districts to help them curb their spending and get the most out of every tax dollar.

docs.lead_paragraph: In an economy characterized by large-scale layoffs and growing insecurity, American workers have become increasingly reluctant to take the risky step of going on strike, causing the number of strikes last year to fall to the lowest level since World War II. Despite the periodic outbreak of titanic battles, like the 69-day strike against Boeing and the 18-month walkout against Caterpillar, there were just 32 strikes last year involving 1,000 workers or more, half the amount of a decade ago and one-eighth the level two decades ago.
